items.title: How Europeโs new carbon tax on imported goods will change global trade
items.summary: The new regulation arrives on New Year's Day.
items.body: For people living in the European Union, the price of their next car, home renovation, and even local produce may soon reflect a climate policy that many have never even heard of. This new regulation, which comes fully into force on New Yearโs Day, does not just target heavy industryโit affects everyday goods which now face an added carbon cost when they enter Europe. The carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) puts a carbon price on many imported goodsโmeaning that EU-based importers will pay for the greenhouse gases emitted during the production of certain carbon-intensive materials. If goods come from countries with weaker climate rules, then the charge will be higher. To sell to the EU, producers will effectively need to show their goods arenโt too carbon-intensive. items.title: Google lobs lawsuit at search result scraping firm SerpApi
items.summary: Google says the lawsuit is its last resort.
items.body: Google has filed a lawsuit to protect its search results, targeting a firm called SerpApi that has turned Googleโs 10 blue links into a business. According to Google, SerpApi ignores established law and Googleโs terms to scrape and resell its search engine results pages (SERPs). This is not the first action against SerpApi, but Googleโs decision to go after a scraper could signal a new, more aggressive stance on protecting its search data. SerpApi and similar firms do fulfill a need, but they sit in a legal gray area. Google does not provide an API for its search results, which are based on the worldโs largest and most comprehensive web index. That makes Googleโs SERPs especially valuable in the age of AI. A chatbot canโt summarize web links if it canโt find them, which has led companies like Perplexity to pay for SerpApiโs second-hand Google data. That prompted Reddit to file a lawsuit against SerpApi and Perplexity for grabbing its data from Google results. Google is echoing many of the things Reddit said when it publicized its lawsuit earlier this year. The search giant claims itโs not just doing this to protect itselfโitโs also about protecting the websites it indexes. In Googโฆ

items.title: The evolution of expendability: Why some ants traded armor for numbers
items.summary: Ants with lots of workers tend to put less energy into making them armored.
items.body: The trade-off between quality and quantity is a fundamental economic dilemma. Now, a team of British, American, and Japanese researchers describes how it applies to biology, as well. They have discovered that this dilemma most likely shaped the evolutionary trajectory of ants, one of Earthโs most successful groups of organisms. Their study reveals that, as ant societies grew in complexity and numbers, they didnโt just make their workers smallerโthey also made them cheaper. The cost of armor In the insect world, the exoskeleton known as the cuticle serves as a protective barrier against predators, pathogens, and desiccation, while providing the structural framework for muscle attachment. But this protection comes at a price. Building a robust cuticle requires significant amounts of nitrogen and rare minerals like zinc and manganese. While skimping on armor for an individual insect may be a death sentence, the evolution of ants apparently found a way around it. Read full article Comments

items.title: Switch 2 pub backs off Game Key Cards after leaking lower-cost cartridge options
items.summary: Inin suggests new low-cost options allowed it to "recalculate production" for full cartridge.
items.body: The Switch 2โs data-free, download-enabling Game Key Cards have proved controversial with players who worry about long-term ownership and access issues to their purchases. But theyโve remained popular with publishers that want to save production costs on a boxed Switch 2 game release, since Game Key Cards donโt include any of the expensive flash memory found on a standard Switch 2 cartridge. Now, though, at least one publisher has publicly suggested that Nintendo is offering cheaper Switch 2 cartridge options with smaller storage capacities, lowering production costs in a way that could make full cartridge releases more viable for many games on the console. Earlier this week , R-Type Dimensions III publisher Inin Games explained to customers that it couldnโt switch from Game Key Cards to a โfull physical cartridgeโ for the retail version of the Switch 2 game without โsignificantly rais[ing] manufacturing costs.โ Those additional costs would โforce us to increase the retail price by at least โฌ15 [about $20],โ Inin Games wrote at the time. items.title: Riot Games is making an anti-cheat change that could be rough on older PCs
items.summary: BIOS checks will only affect a limited subset of Valorant players for now.
items.body: At this point, most competitive online multiplayer games on the PC come with some kind of kernel-level anti-cheat software . As weโve written before , this is software that runs with more elevated privileges than most other apps and games you run on your PC, allowing it to load in earlier and detect advanced methods of cheating. More recently, anti-cheat software has started to require more Windows security features like Secure Boot , a TPM 2.0 module, and virtualization-based memory integrity protection . Riot Games, best known for titles like Valorant and League of Legends and the Vanguard anti-cheat software, has often been one of the earliest to implement new anti-cheat requirements. Thereโs already a long list of checks that systems need to clear before theyโll be allowed to play Riotโs games online, and now the studio is announcing a new one : a BIOS update requirement that will be imposed on โcertain playersโ following Riotโs discovery of a UEFI bug that could allow especially dedicated and motivated cheaters to circumvent certain memory protections. In short, the bug affects the input-output memory management unit (IOMMU) โon some UEFI-based motherboards from multiple vendโฆ

items.title: Not too big, not too expensive: The Chevrolet Equinox EV
items.summary: You get quite a lot of EV for the Equinox's sub-$35,000 starting price.
items.body: Thereโs a lot of goodwill out there for the Chevrolet Bolt . As maybe the first properly affordable longer-range electric car on the market, the Bolt wasnโt perfect. It didnโt charge very fast, and people found the seats quite uncomfortable. But it could get more than 230 miles on a single chargeโa lot in 2017โand you didnโt have to be flush to afford one. Oh, and it was also pretty good to drive. I know I was a fan from the first time I tried a prototype at CES in 2016. Understandably, Bolt fans were upset when Chevy decided to kill off the car . Yes, it lacked features compared to more modern EVs, but it is also the brandโs bestselling EV by quite a country mile. โNot to worry,โ said the executives, who told us they had something better coming built on the platform they used to call Ultium but donโt anymore. Starting at around the same $35,000 price tag the Bolt launched with, this would be the new Equinox EV. That $34,995 price tag was perhaps a bit more appealing when the car was eligible for the now-dead $7,500 IRS clean vehicle tax credit. Truth be told, the LT1 spec is a little bare-boned, and youโll need to step up to the LT2 we testedโwhich starts at $40,295โif you want tโฆ

items.title: Trumpโs energy secretary orders a Washington state coal plant to remain open
items.summary: Chris Wright declared an energy โemergencyโ in the Pacific Northwest.
items.body: SEATTLEโThe last coal-fired power plant in Washington state was set to go cold at the end of the year. It would then switch to natural gas, cutting carbon emissions in half. The shutdown had been in the works for 15 years and was mandated by state law. It required the Canadian energy company that owns the power plant, TransAlta, to retrain workers and ease the local communityโs economic transition. But the farewell to coal was canceled this week by the Trump administration. In furtherance of the presidentโs crusade to keep Americaโs coal plants burning, the Department of Energy announced Tuesday that an โemergency existsโ in the Pacific Northwest โdue to a shortage of electricity.โ To keep the lights on, Energy Secretary Chris Wright said that the Centralia electric generating facility in southwest Washington must continue to burn coal for at least 90 more days. items.body: Instacart has agreed to pay out $60 million in subscriber refunds, the Federal Trade Commission announced on Thursday. The refunds will help settle a lawsuit the FTC raised, accusing the grocery delivery app of engaging in โnumerous unlawful tactics that harmed shoppers and raised the cost of grocery shopping for Americans.โ Under the settlementโwhich expires after 10 yearsโInstacart agreed to stop marketing its app with allegedly deceptive claims. That includes supposedly offering โfree delivery,โ when customers actually paid up to 15 percent in โservice feesโ not charged for pickup orders. Those service fees, the FTC alleged, were โjust delivery fees by another name.โ Read full article Comments

items.title: We asked four AI coding agents to rebuild Minesweeperโthe results were explosive
items.summary: How do four modern LLMs do at re-creating a simple Windows gaming classic?
items.body: The idea of using AI to help with computer programming has become a contentious issue. On the one hand, coding agents can make horrific mistakes that require a lot of inefficient human oversight to fix, leading many developers to lose trust in the concept altogether . On the other hand, some coders insist that AI coding agents can be powerful tools and that frontier models are quickly getting better at coding in ways that overcome some of the common problems of the past. To see how effective these modern AI coding tools are becoming, we decided to test four major models with a simple task: re-creating the classic Windows game Minesweeper . Since itโs relatively easy for pattern-matching systems like LLMs to play off of existing code to re-create famous games, we added in one novelty curveball as well. Our straightforward prompt: Read full article Comments

items.body: After a year of stalled negotiations, TikTok owner ByteDance has reportedly agreed to Donald Trumpโs deal giving US owners majority ownership of the app. By signing the agreements, ByteDance has ended a prolonged period of uncertainty for millions of Americans who rely on TikTok for news, entertainment, social connection, and income. Under a law that Trump declined to enforceโwhich lawmakers convinced the Supreme Court was critical for national securityโTikTok risked a US ban next year if the sale did not go through. According to Reuters , terms of the deal match what was reported in September when Trump controversially confirmed that ByteDance would keep the algorithm . items.title: Two space startups prove you donโt need to break the bank to rendezvous in space
items.summary: "We had to push the envelope a little bit here."
items.body: It may be happening quietly, but there is a revolution taking place with in-space transportation, and it opens up a world of possibilities. In January, a small spacecraft built by a California-based company called Impulse Space launched along with a stack of other satellites on a Falcon 9 rocket. Upon reaching orbit, the rocketโs upper stage sent the satellites zipping off on their various missions. And so it went with the Mira spacecraft built by Impulse, which is known as an orbital transfer vehicle. Mira dropped off several small CubeSats and then performed a number of high-thrust maneuvers to demonstrate its capabilities. This was the second flight by a Mira spacecraft, so Impulse Space was eager to continue testing the vehicle in flight. Read full article Comments

items.title: Parasites plagued Roman soldiers at Hadrianโs Wall
items.summary: They were infected by roundworm, whipworm, and microscopic protozoans called Giardia duodenalis.
items.body: It probably sucked to be a Roman soldier guarding Hadrianโs Wall circa the third century CE. W.H. Auden imagined the likely harsh conditions in his poem โ Roman Wall Blues ,โ in which a soldier laments enduring wet wind and rain with โlice in my tunic and a cold in my nose.โ We can now add chronic nausea and bouts of diarrhea to his list of likely woes, thanks to parasitic infections, according to a new paper published in the journal Parasitology. As previously reported , archaeologists can learn a great deal by studying the remains of intestinal parasites in ancient feces. For instance, in 2022, we reported on an analysis of soil samples collected from a stone toilet found within the ruins of a swanky 7th-century BCE villa just outside Jerusalem. That analysis revealed the presence of parasitic eggs from four different species: whipworm, beef/pork tapeworm, roundworm, and pinworm. (Itโs the earliest record of roundworm and pinworm in ancient Israel.) Later that same year, researchers from the University of Cambridge and the University of British Columbia analyzed the residue on an ancient Roman ceramic pot excavated at the site of a 5th-century CE Roman villa at Gerace, a rural dโฆ

items.title: YouTube bans two popular channels that created fake AI movie trailers
items.summary: Google loves AI content, except when it doesn't.
items.body: Google is generally happy to see people using generative AI tools to create content, and itโs doubly happy when they publish it on its platforms. But there are limits to everything. Two YouTube channels that attracted millions of subscribers with AI-generated movie trailers have been shuttered. Screen Culture and KH Studio flooded the site with fake but often believable trailers. The channels, which had a combined audience of more than 2 million subscribers, became a thorn in Googleโs side in early 2025 when other YouTubers began griping about their sudden popularity in the age of AI. The channels produced videos with titles like โGTA: San Andreas (2025) Teaser Trailerโ and โMalcom In The Middle Reboot (2025) First Trailer.โ Of course, neither of those projects exist, but that didnโt stop them from appearing in user feeds. Google demonetized the channels in early 2025, forcing them to adopt language that made it clear they were not official trailers. The channels were able to monetize again, but the disclaimers were not consistently used. Indeed, many of the most popular videos from those channels in recent months included no โparodyโ or โconcept trailerโ disclosures. Now, visitinโฆ

items.body: Peacock subscribers will see ads immediately upon opening the streaming app or website next year. Itโs a bold new strategy for attracting advertisersโsomething thatโs been increasingly important to subscription-based streaming servicesโbut it also risks alienating viewers As reported by Variety , the new type of ads will display on the profile selection page that shows when a subscriber launches Peacock. Starting next year, instead of the profile page just showing your different Peacock profiles, most of the page will be dominated by an advertorial image. The circles of NBCUniversal-owned characters selected for user profiles will be relegated to a vertical column on the screenโs left side, as you can see here . To avoid seeing what NBCUniversal is calling โArrival Adsโ every time you open Peacock, you need to subscribe to Peacockโs most expensive plan, which is ad-free and starts at $17 per month (Peacockโs ad-based plans start at $8/month.)
